content.description: Easy crack climb with some stemming. Easy to set up TR.
content.protection: Tie off trees or build anchor with gear.
content.location: Corner crack in second alcove from the left side of crag.

content.description: Follows a thin crack up to the tree at the edge of the cliff. Stay mostly to the right, then traverse left across the top of the slab and onto a small shelf below the tree. Could be made more difficult/exposed by climbing more of the left slab.
content.location: Around the corner (to the right) from the roof. Tree anchor for this climb can be used for TR to the left.

content.description: Climb to the right of the big roof. Climb up the face, finger jam the crack in the dihedral, work your way up, and pull the roof to the anchor.
content.protection: Tree anchor at the top of the cliff, can be built from above.

content.description: Easy start to a tricky crux working past the bulge. Trust the solid feet and blast past on so-so hands to the finish.Â Anchor is a little tricky, have some extra slings/long cordelette.
content.protection: C4 #4 and 5 were nice for protecting the middle. Gear/natural anchor.
content.location: Middle of the clearing in the middle of the crag. South facing corner.

content.description: Crack that goes right from the ugly looking OW.
content.location: 3rd Alcove from the left side of crag.

content.description: Following the crack straight up. A deceptively straightforward looking climb from the ground it takes a bit of thought and trust in vague feet. Fun though could be a dicey lead if you're not super solid. Stem out right and/or use the offwidth to make life maybe more bearable.If you build the anchor just right you can flip it around the corner (climber's left) and use the same placements for that climb as well after adjusting your master point.
content.protection: standard rack. Gear anchor (we used a C4 0.3, 0.4, and 1) bring a long cordelette.
content.location: Third alcove from the left of the crag (right next to Unknown 5.5)

content.description: Excellent early lead. Great stances and you can really sew it up. Some nice moves sprinkled in too!
content.protection: Standard rack. Gear anchor (can use the same placements as the 5.7 around the corner.
content.location: Middle-left of crag. It'll be where the trail narrows before opening up into a small clearing at the middle of the crag.

content.description: Another south facing dihedral feature. A couple smooth moves to a nice horizontal crack at the mini "roof" leads to the crux pulling on the thin ledge onto the face to the right. Be sure to get an absolutely bomber piece into that vertical crack before pulling the move and have an attentive belay here. The ground fall would not be pretty. Eases up considerably to a nice saunter up the crack to the top.Anchor is a little tricky. Either large pieces or go far climber's left to a crack that'll take several small pieces. Bring a long cordelette and a couple supplemental slings. do NOT sling the jammed log or stump right at the top of the climb.
content.protection: Standard rack. Gear anchor. do NOT sling the log or stump at the top
content.location: 2 mini corners climber's left of the clearing at the middle of the crag.

content.description: Follow the crack/ramp on the right side of this alcove.
content.location: 2nd alcove from the left side of crag. Right side.

content.description: Good beginner route. Easy to set up TR.

Small crag right next to the Sandia Ranger Station. Good beginner area. Easy to set up topropes. Short routes (30') with a good variety of face & crack. A couple of good overhangs for bouldering and traversing.
